stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on designing the main entrance hall of an ice castle level. The primary activity was brainstorming and solving the central puzzle for the first star: making it visible from the start but accessible only after navigating a portion of the level. This led to the redesign of the entrance layout and the decision to use a giant, rollable snowball as the solution.

development_findings.summary: Kaze conceptualized a new swinging chandelier mechanic but identified a major technical hurdle: it would require complex quaternion math not present in the SM64 engine. He decided to simplify the mechanic by locking its movement to one axis.
development_findings.quote: God do I have to program the entire quaternion math we don't have any of that in r64 yet it seems quite excessive.

development_findings.summary: An effect for appearing platforms was significantly improved. Instead of just appearing, the platforms now form from a growing snowflake pattern, a change Kaze was very proud of and for which he credited fellow contributor Samah.
development_findings.quote: You see how they now grow first and then like they slowly grow into the whole thing it's not as abrupt anymore. I like that a lot.

development_findings.summary: The central puzzle for the first star evolved from a simple idea to a multi-step solution involving rolling a giant snowball to smash an ice wall, which required a significant redesign of the level's entrance hall.
The intro sequence for the Raven boss fight is planned in detail, aiming for a dramatic, cinematic reveal involving a lunar eclipse effect.
development_findings.quote: The boss fight is gonna be on top of the castle and there's gonna be the moon behind it... and then out of the pure black you see two eyes just opening up and that's the boss intro.

development_findings.summary: Kaze expressed concern that the level might run into memory limitations rather than performance issues, which influences decisions about how assets are implemented (e.g., making statues destructible objects instead of part of the level geometry).
The level design is influenced by Snowpeak Ruins from The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess, specifically the idea that rooms should feel like they serve a real purpose within the mansion.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a strong aversion to updating software, believing updates primarily introduce new problems. This philosophy influences his development environment, and he is considering switching from Windows to Linux to avoid forced updates.
context_findings.quote: Everytime software updates it introduces new bugs and I have to get used to new bugs. The old bugs I'm already used to.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy prioritizes finalizing platforming mechanics and level layout before applying thematic details like room purposes (e.g., library, diner).
context_findings.quote: The theming should be secondary to the gameplay.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is working despite a painful knee injury that makes it difficult to sit, indicating a high level of dedication but also highlighting physical strain.

When deciding how to solve a puzzle, Kaze rejects a simple solution (using a Bomb Cap) in favor of a more creative, integrated mechanic (the snowball), prioritizing player experience and ingenuity over ease of implementation.
context_findings.quote: I'd rather show them a cool idea.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided a 3D model for the swinging chandelier, which Kaze discovered had duplicate triangles that needed to be fixed.

zeina.summary: Kaze consulted Zeina for her artistic opinion on whether a penguin statue model should be flat-shaded or smooth-shaded.
Zeina created a low-poly penguin statue model that Kaze integrated into the level, praising its appearance and texture work.

key_stories.title: The Star in the Ice Wall Puzzle
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled to design the puzzle for the first star, wanting it to be a visible but unreachable goal. After discarding several overly complex or simple ideas, he settled on having the player roll a giant snowball to smash an ice wall, redesigning the level's entrance to support this single, cohesive mechanic.
key_stories.challenge: The level's first star needed to be visible from the entrance to create a central mystery for the player, but the initial layout made this impossible.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed putting the star behind a large ice wall. To break it, he considered and rejected a mandatory power-up (Bomb Cap) as uncreative and a complex swinging chandelier as too difficult to program and use. He ultimately settled on the idea of the player finding a giant snowball on an upper path and rolling it down to smash the ice.
key_stories.outcome: The snowball solution was chosen. Kaze redesigned the entrance hall with large, spiral staircases that both frame the view of the ice wall and serve as a natural slide for the snowball, creating a cohesive and satisfying puzzle.
key_stories.key_quote: I want that when you enter this area here the first thing you see... is you see a star but you have no idea how to get there and it's supposed to like stick in your minds.

key_stories.title: The Swinging Chandelier Mechanic
key_stories.summary: Kaze designed a new swinging chandelier mechanic but faced significant technical challenges. He simplified the design to make it easier to program and more intuitive for the player, ultimately deciding to use it as a general platforming obstacle rather than for the main puzzle it was originally intended for.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze wanted to add a new, dynamic platforming element to the castle and conceived of a large, swinging chandelier.
key_stories.process: Kaze conceptualized a mechanic where players would shift Mario's weight to build momentum. He recognized the programming would be extremely complex (requiring quaternion math). To make it feasible to code and easier for players to control, he simplified the concept to only swing on a single axis.
key_stories.outcome: While the chandelier was deemed unsuitable for the main star puzzle, Kaze decided the mechanic was still valuable and could be repurposed for other platforming sections within the level.
key_stories.key_quote: The easier for the player thing is what really makes me want to do it.
